user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut(osal_id_t queue_id, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;
    OS_queue_internal_record_t *queue;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(data);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(size);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        queue = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_queue_table, token);

        if (size > queue->max_size)
        {
            /*
            ** The buffer that the user is passing in is too large
            */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_QueuePut_Impl(&token, data, size, flags);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueuePut:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in this function. Specifically:
- queue_id is passed by value to OS_ObjectIdGetById and is not assigned to or altered anywhere in the function.
- data is declared const void * and only used in the null-check macro (OS_CHECK_POINTER) and passed unchanged to OS_QueuePut_Impl; there is no assignment to the data parameter itself.
- size is validated with OS_CHECK_SIZE and compared to queue->max_size, but is not assigned to or modified.
- flags is passed through to OS_QueuePut_Impl without modification.
- The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) do not perform assignments to the function parameters; OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET takes the address of the local token, not of any function parameter.

The only potential modifications occur to the local variable token (via OS_ObjectIdGetById) and to the object pointed to by data may be modified by OS_QueuePut_Impl, but that would be within that callee, not a modification of OS_QueuePut's parameters. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
